node.title: Plastic strain rate coupled with concentration
node.bodyText:
Hi @hugary1995 ,
I am trying to implement the last term of this equation and can be reduce as follows (with CL and epsilon_p as the two variables):


It consist of a strain rate coupled with concentration_lattice (CL) and the stress-strain variation is as follows:

Here is what I have tried:

Introduce the effective plastic strain as an ADProperty

[Materials]



Insert the property as an non-linear variable strain_p




Used ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative kernels to solve:



[]

Could you check if I am correct till here, implementing the kernel, if yes, how do I implemeny the stress-strain relationships?

Take a look at the plasticity/creep regression tests in modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests. If you set things up correctly, epsilon_p will be available as equivalent_plastic_strain or equivalent_inelastic_strain.
You don't need to project the epsilon_p onto a field, because you don't need its gradients. I suggest you implement your own kernel representing this term. If you don't know how to write a custom kernel, check out the tutorials and the workshop.

Hi @hugary1995,
Yes, I will try to build a custom kernel, could you suggest, how do I implement any stress-strain relationship as such?

By "implement", do you mean that you want to write source code to perform the constitutive update, or do you want to use already implemented materials in the tensor_mechanics module? The former is usually what I mean by "implementing" something, but I realize you may be referring to the latter.
Either way, I recommend you to start with the tensor_mechanics documentation, as always. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/index.html
On the right side there is a column listing "advanced features", where you will find descriptions on "Multiple inelastic stress", "Crystal plasticity", "Viscoplasticity", etc.. Then, look at the input files inside modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests for additional examples on how to set up these models.

Hi @GiudGiud , I want to couple the plastic strain eP with conc, cL. Which is the correct way to do so, the cL here is the primary variable?

[Variables]
  [./cL]
  [../]

  [./eP]
  [../]
[]


Using ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative:

[Kernels]
  [./CL_time_term]
    type = ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = 'cL'
    specific_heat = '1'
    density_name = 'func1'
  [../]

  [./strain_effective]
    type = ADMaterialPropertyValue
    prop_name = 'effective_plastic_strain'
    variable = 'eP'
  [../]


[Materials]
  [./diff_time]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    expression = 'if(eP < 0.5, (2/3)*cL + eP, (1/2)*cL)'
    args = 'cL	eP'
    property_name = 'func1'
  [../]


Using ADCoupledMatTimeDerivative

  [./strainrate_term]
    type = ADCoupledMatTimeDerivative
    variable = 'eP'
    v = 'cL'
    coef = 'func2'
  [../]

  [./strain_effective]
    type = ADMaterialPropertyValue
    prop_name = 'effective_plastic_strain'
    variable = 'eP'
  [../]


[Materials]
  [./diff_time]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    expression = 'if(eP < 0.5, (2/3)*cL + eP, (1/2)*cL)'
    args = 'cL	eP'
    property_name = 'func2'
  [../]

node.title: Array Variable Solution IC
node.bodyText:
Greetings everyone,
I wanted to ask about the possibility of using the SolutionIC / SolutionUserObject procedure to initialize an array variable.
It seems to me that, at the moment, this is not possible ( "// We can handle only FIRST order scalar variables" is written in the SolutionUserObject source file, and if I try to follow the example at /moose/test/tests/ics/solution_ic/solution_ic.i with array variable, I get a "_Map_base::at" error).
Is there any other procedure that is standard for this purpose?
I realize that one could for instance use an "ArrayConstantIC", but I would much rather be able to just carry over solution values from a previous simulation.
For context, I am looking to use the solution of the k eigenproblem for the multigroup diffusion equation as the initial condition for a transient, where the initial precursor distribution is calculated with an auxkernel.
In case the solution would indeed be to produce an array version of SolutionIC / SolutionUserObject, I could try to take a stab at it. Is there any reason this would be impractical?
Thanks for your time,
Gabriele

Hello
You probably wont want to initialize every variable manually from SolutionICs + a SolutionUO, even though I think we should be able to make it work with a (newly created) SolutionArrayIC.
I would recommend trying either of these two techniques to initialize everything at once:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html
Guillaume
if you want to code up the SolutionArrayIC we would love to have it in moose btw

Thanks for the solution.
I do have a followup question, since it appears that now the flux variables are being correctly copied from the checkpoint file, but the precursor auxiliary variables are not.
By using postprocessors to compute the integrals, I can tell that the precursor concentrations are all set to zero in the beginning of the transient simulation (unlike the fluxes, whose integral are the same as those in TIMESTEP_END of the eigenvalue calculation).
Is this due to the fact that I am trying to copy auxiliary variables into normal ones?
Is there any other syntax/flag that I should add in this case?
I am using what I think are the standard advanced restart commands:
[Outputs]
[cp]
type = Checkpoint
execute_on = TIMESTEP_END 
[]
[]


[Mesh]
file = eigen_cp_cp/0001-mesh.cpr
[]

[Problem]
restart_file_base = eigen_cp_cp/LATEST  
[]

Also this doesn't seem to be due to the execution flag on the auxiliary kernels for the precusors in the eigenvalue calculation, which I have tried changing without result.
I would be very grateful for any indication about what's going wrong.
Thanks again,
Gabriele

Hello
Can you please paste the auxkernel and auxvariables block?
The change of system is indeed the problem.
I think the ArraySolutionIC is the solution for this
Guillaume

Is this due to the fact that I am trying to copy auxiliary variables into normal ones?

Are you saying precursor concentrations are aux variables in the eigenvalue calculation but primal variables during transient? If so, I think the restart system cannot handle this. @GiudGiud has commented. I think @loganharbour will be working on a capability that allows users to restart individual items from a checkpoint file, which will have a similar syntax like Variables/*/initial_from_file_var. But you may need to wait for a while on this.
Thank you both for the information, indeed it is the case that precursor would have gone from auxiliary to primal

Looks like a bunch of "eigensolver"-like tests all require SLEPc. Lets run those tests specifically:
cd moose/test
make -j 6
./run_tests --re=eigensolvers

node.title: Adding Bloch boundary condition in moose
node.bodyText: I want to add bloch type boundary condition for a wave propagation problem that I am solving. The  boundary condition is applied on both the displacement and stress (gradient of displacement). There are two files I found in moose AddPeriodicBCAction.c and FunctionPeriodicBoundary.c. Can someone help me with how to proceed?

I was trying to implement the suggestion in this #16419 by @crswong888. Ran into a problem of using complex number to signify the complex number  i in $\exp(ikx)$ in the bloch periodic boundary condition. Any ideas how to solve this problem ?
Basically incorporating the bloch periodic boundary condition i.e.
$u_2 = u_1 * \exp(ikx)$
using penalty formulation.

Hello
You ll want to split your equation in the real and imaginary part.
Are u2 and u1 both complex numbers?

No. So I'm solving an eigenvalue problem to get dispersion curves. The displacements will get eliminated. The unknowns are wave number and eigenfrequency
$K - \omega^2 M = 0$
Thanks for the quick reply. I am new to moose but the community is very helpful
Can you split this K - w2 M  equation in its real and imaginary part?

once you have the stress in real & imaginary part, you have to add this stress term in the solid mechanics equation.
Are you planning to use the solid mechanics module? Or implement every equation yourself

I dont see sigma in your first equation?
Does it come in through C?
The equilibrium equation is simplified by substituting the constitutive relation $\sigma = C\epsilon$

ok I see now.
is epsilon related to u ?
You have two complex variables, you ll likely need two (complex) equations to have a well posed problem.
The first equation can be solved as two real equations with the right combination of kernels for each.
The boundary conditions can either be written as periodic BC if the size of the domain is right on the period (2 pi / k )?

$\epsilon = 1/2(\nabla u + \nabla u^T)$
Regarding the complex variables, in the literature they are using the same mesh consdiering uim and ur as separate components.
PeriodicBC won't work because we need to vary the value of k within the first Briollouin zone which can be like $[0,2\pi/a]$ to obtain omega for each. The goal is get the dispersion curves which is $\omega$ vs $k$ graph. PeriodicBC supports only $u(x + h_i) = u(x)$

ok epsilon is strain.

in the literature they are using the same mesh consdiering uim and ur as separate components.

ok good, we can do that.
ok no periodic BC.
How big is the solve going to be? I have a solution using functors, but it's not going to work in parallel without a lot more work.
Oh that's great. Parallel implementation won't be necessary. I will be using only 2-D mesh.

`[Mesh]
[First]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
elem_type = EDGE
dim =  1
xmin = 0
xmax = 10
nx = 10
[]
[]

[]

[]
[]

variable = ur
[]
[diff2]

[]

variable = ur
[]

variable = uim
[]
[]
[BCs]
[]

[./disp_x_1]
type = LinearNodalConstraint
variable = ur

primary = left
weights = '0.7071 -0.7071'
secondary_node_set = right
penalty = 1e8
formulation = penalty
[../]
[./disp_x_1]
type = LinearNodalConstraint
variable = uim
variable_secondary = ur uim
primary = left
weights = '-0.7071 0.7071'
secondary_node_set = right
penalty = 1e8
formulation = penalty
[../]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Eigenvalue
eigen_problem_type = gen_non_hermitian
which_eigen_pairs = SMALLEST_MAGNITUDE
n_eigen_pairs = 5
n_basis_vectors = 18
solve_type = jacobi_davidson
petsc_options = '-eps_view'
[]
[Outputs]
exodus = true
[]'
This is the inp file I wrote for the case so far.
This is for the bloch boundary condition for displacement right ? But displacement boundary condition I can  apply using LinearNodalConstraint. It is the traction boundary condition where I am stuck.
Ok. will look into FunctorNeumannBC also ang get back. Thanks!

ah good point. I lost track.
Yes if you can formulate it as a FunctorNeumannBC that could work.

https://github.com/adhithya96/Static1D
I tried out what you had suggested. BlochDirichletBC.C and BlochDirichletBC.h. (I couldn't upload all the files. Have to set up the github repository locally. will do it in a few days). I got these errors.
'const class std::unique_ptrlibMesh::PointLocatorBase' has no member named 'locate_node'
54 |   const auto new_node = pl.locate_node(_current_node + _translation_vector);
|                            ^~~~~~~~~~~
/home/adhithyar/Documents/Project/static1d/src/BlochDirichletBC.C:54:56: error: '_translation_vector' was not declared in this scope
54 |   const auto new_node = pl.locate_node(_current_node + _translation_vector);
Couple of questions I have.

What does the _functor and _coeff do ?
I was also trying to write a similar code for Neumann case. How do I mention the gradient of u on the one side of periodic boundary condition ?
Is there anyway to learn how the code is written ?

yes this was pseudo code. You have to find the actual names of the routines
see the doxygen
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1PointLocatorBase.html
you need to add _translation_vector to the header too

Functor and coef can be evaluated anywhere on the mesh and provide the local field value
From a functor, you can get the gradient with _functor.gradient(r,t)
Use the doxygen. Or the VSCode integration that's also super helpful. And look at other objects in the folders

[]

In the code  we don't write for every point in the specified boundary.

A node can be caster to a point automatically. But a node pointer is not.
Just do *_current_node to get a Node and it can be used in lieu of a Point
The dirichlet BC is applied on every node that is part of the 'nodeset' boundary

node.title: Access out of bounds in MooseArray error in dg kernels

I am not sure what led to this error. Do you have any ideas?
Best,

what is the current moose commit you used? (from a git log)
and did you recompile the dbg executable? Is there any chance the dbg one is old?

Here is the moose commit
commit 864c841f750c0272a19edbf8ee225410768f8555 (HEAD, origin/scheduled, origin/master)

is it the same commit at the beginning of the simulation log?

MOOSE Version:           git commit 4a2dd93b74 on 2024-03-13

Install on a clean machine (linux, conda environment) failed with
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'yaml'
The error already occured during build, but the build still finished. However, running any tests fails instantly.
The common advice on the net is to install pyyaml. However, this is already installed:

# packages in environment at /home/.local/wuha/miniforge/envs/moose:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'yaml'

Any recommendation? Thanks in advance!

Hello
you can also install yaml.
conda install yaml
Guillaume

I think its actually pyaml you want. This will get the shared libraries for yaml and the Python module to interface with it import yaml. Can you believe all these exist and are different!?:

:)

yaml and pyyaml were installed, pyaml was missing. Issues is solved. Please consider adding the module to the dependency package you get with
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.03.15

It might be that there are two instances of Conda possibly fighting eachother. I don't know what the right solution here is, except to remove one. Probably the mambaforge variant, as that is a deprecated Conda instance as of last September. You probably have that due to MOOSE using mambaforge last year :)

There was a version with mambaforge on the previous computer, with a different system etc.
I copied lots of data to the new one, but I am not aware of copying anything related to conda.

cat ~/.bashrc
cat ~/.bash_profile

It seems mambaforge3 is going to be somewhere... since I also notice conda info --all printed out your PATH variable, and it too is listing a mambaforge3/bin PATH. Of course, missing directories among PATH should be okay, and therefor if this location physically does not exist, then I doubt mambaforge3 is getting in the way.
Still, there is some oddness. A proper installation of Conda, should result in the following which returns:
❯ which python python3 conda
/Users/milljm/miniforge3/envs/moose/bin/python
/Users/milljm/miniforge3/envs/moose/bin/python3
conda () {
	\local cmd="${1-__missing__}"
	case "$cmd" in
		(activate | deactivate) __conda_activate "$@" ;;
		(install | update | upgrade | remove | uninstall) __conda_exe "$@" || \return
			__conda_reactivate ;;
		(*) __conda_exe "$@" ;;
	esac
}
where conda is a function, and not a path to the actual binary which is being reported by your which conda statement.
The reason why its working "now" is because we sourced the moose environment manually, properly. But we shouldn't have to do this. conda activate moose should suffice.

node.title: How to get the value of the ArrayVariable at the end of the last nonlinear iteration
node.bodyText: In each iteration of the steady-state calculation, I need the value of the array variable in the previous iteration, but I don't know how to get it. Thanks for the answer.   : )

Hello
You can use the functor interfaces with a previous nonlinear state on the variable
This one https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classMoose_1_1FunctorBase.html#a9ebde35cd92b43d6ccad6143f96bedec
and use it in a new auxkernel
Guillaume
Thanks for your help, I'm going to take a closer look.

I am not sure what exactly you are looking for. Maybe you want to study this test https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/executioners/fixed_point/nonlinear_fixed_point.i , which uses vector tagging and has a custom solve object with fixed point iterations.

node.title: How do I get rid of spikes in my simulation result?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
My simulation was successful with the expected result. However, the result show too many spikes. How do I get rid of these spikes? I’m using IterationAdaptiveDT with dt_min = 1e-3. When I removed the IterationAdaptiveDT, I don't see the spikes, but my results deviated slightly from what I would expect. I want to use the iterative adaptive time-stepping. Any suggestion on how I can do this without the spikes? Thanks.
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = Newton
  end_time = 3e3
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-9
  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1e-3          
    optimal_iterations = 10
  []
[]

Hello
What kind of spikes are they? In time? or in the spatial solution?
My worry with spikes would be that you have false convergence happening. Change nl_abs_tol = 1e-9 this back to the default. Removing the line will do that
Guillaume

Hello,
The spikes occur in time. After changing the tolerance to the default value, I got a convergence error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "IterationAdaptiveDT", of type "IterationAdaptiveDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at dtmin, cannot continue!

ok can you turn on automatic scaling then set a reasonably tight tolerance.
automatic scaling will normalize the tolerances
Hello @GiudGiud, my simulation fails to converge after setting a tight tolerance and using automatic scaling.  Any other suggestion to make the IterationAdaptiveDT work without the spike? Thanks.

I dont think the time stepper is the problem here. They simply create the time grid. They both can be made to have a sufficiently fine time step for your problem.
Two things could be happening here:

the time steps are not well selected and in the first oscillating case you were violating a CFL-like condition, causing stability issues
the convergence criteria were loosened and the results started oscillating because they were not converged.

Could you please paste the executioner block?

Hi @GiudGiud, here is the executioner block that I used:
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = Newton
  end_time = 3e3
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-11
  [TimeStepper]
  type = ConstantDT
  dt = 1
  []
[]

the executioner looks fine to me.
nl_abs_tol of 1e-11 is probably fine enough. I like to use automatic_scaling = true in that block to normalize the convergence criteria but I see you already have manual scaling in the simulation so it's probably already fine.
I think looking at the IterativeAdaptiveDT time steps might show you if they were too big for the problem
Hello @GiudGiud, how do I output the iterativeAdaptiveDT time steps? Should I use the output system to do this?
You can use a TimeStepSize post processor to save each time step into a csv file

Hello @GiudGiud @cpgr, thanks for the feedback. Now I know why I'm getting spikes in the result. Is there a way to maintain the time steps in a simulation when using constantDT without the time step fluctuating at certain times? For example, I set dt=4 using constantDT, but the time step is not constant during the simulation. It fluctuates from 4 to 2 at certain times, corresponding to the spikes. Is there a way (or time stepper) to force the time step to remain at a specific value throughout the simulation even if any fluctuation occurs?

Hello
The fluctuations are probably due to time steps failing? What does the log say?
I think you are having convergence issues here. You need to work on getting clean nonlinear solve convergence. Maybe that will force a reduction of the time step. Maybe you can work with the executioner parameters (maybe automatic scaling?) to get better convergence
Guillaume
Thanks for the tips, @GiudGiud
